Description: The analyzed function `AutofillPopupItemView::OnMouseEntered` only reacts to a mouse-enter event by notifying a controller of the currently hovered line index via `SetSelectedLine(GetLineNumber())`. It neither reads nor outputs user data, configuration, paths, errors, or internal diagnostics; it just passes an integer index internally. There is no logging, UI text generation, or external exposure of potentially sensitive information in this snippet, so it does not present a CWE-200 (information exposure) risk based on the provided code.

The analyzed function `AutofillPopupItemView::OnMouseExited` only retrieves a controller pointer and, if non-null, calls `controller->SelectionCleared()`. It does not log, display, or return any data, nor does it construct error messages, expose internal state, or pass sensitive information to untrusted sinks. Based solely on the provided code, there is no evidence of sensitive information being exposed (CWE-200).

The analyzed function `AutofillPopupItemView::OnMouseReleased` only reacts to a left-mouse-button release within the viewâ€™s bounds and calls `controller->AcceptSuggestion(GetLineNumber())`. The only data passed out is an integer line index corresponding to a selected autofill suggestion; no internal system details, file paths, memory contents, configuration values, or user-specific data are directly exposed or logged here. The callee `GetLineNumber()` simply returns a stored index. There is no evidence in this snippet of logging, error messaging, or other outward channels that would leak sensitive information, and the action (accepting a suggestion based on a UI event) is a normal part of the autofill UI flow. Based solely on the provided code, there is no CWE-200 (information exposure) issue apparent in this function.
